messages.content:
You are tasked with extracting stakeholder information and direct quotes from a given news article related to Ramelius Resources. Your output should be in the form of a markdown table without column titles or any additional information. Each table row should contain:
1. The name of a real person who has expressed a quote in the provided article
2. His role or relation with regards to Ramelius Resources.
3. Their original quote about Ramelius Resources exactly as it appears in the article, without any modifications or translations

Guidelines:
- Include only real people: Exclude organizations, companies, or any other non-person entities
- Direct connection: Ensure that each selected individual is explicitly connected to Ramelius Resources or explicitly express his opinion on Ramelius Resources.
- Only include those whose statements are directly about Ramelius Resources
- Exclude individuals whose comments are not directly relevant to Ramelius Resources or are too general
- Pertinent stakeholders only: Only include the most relevant individuals
- Do not include stakeholders who are not directly associated with Ramelius Resources

Output Format Requirements:
- Each line must contain exactly two columns separated by "|" symbols
- Column 1: Stakeholder's name
- Column 2: Stakeholder's role or link to Ramelius Resources. If not described in the article, try to interpret its role. If it is not straightforward to interpret, mention "Not mentioned".
- Column 3: Original quote in its original language

Example of correct formatting:
| Pierre Dupont | Consumer | "Cette décision de Ramelius Resources est très importante." |
| John Smith | Ramelius Resources's CEO |"We need to review Ramelius Resources's proposal carefully." |
| Hans Weber | Financial analyst | "Die Strategie von Ramelius Resources ist überzeugend." |

If no relevant individuals with quotes are found, return "None."

Article:
Page 1 of 2
Big gains turn miners' eyes to M&A Returns
Big gains turn miners' eyes to M&A; Returns
Australian Financial Review
August 5, 2024 Monday
Print & First Editions
Copyright 2024 Fairfax Media Publications Pty. Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS; Pg. 19
Length: 411 words
Byline: Brad Thompson
Body
West Australian gold producers are poised to capitalise on their riches by turning to mergers and acquisitions 
according to Deloitte, whose annual stocktake of WA-based companies found gold a rare bright spot in a year of 
value destruction for critical minerals.
Companies exposed to green metals and headquartered in the west lost an aggregate $23 billion in market 
capitalisation in 2023-24, the professional services firm found.
The winners were gold miner Red 5, up by 273 per cent as of June 30, Emerald Resources (up 90 per cent) and 
Ramelius Resources (up 76 per cent).
Broadening the field to the top 100 WA companies captures gold play Spartan Resources, which jumped 626 per 
cent, and copper and gold explorer FireFly Metals (up 545 per cent).
Ruling off a year to forget were Hancock-backed lithium producer Liontown Resources down 65 per cent, Delta 
Lithium (down 57 per cent), Lynas Rare Earths (down 13 per cent), Iluka Resources (down 41 per cent) and nickel 
and lithium producer IGO (down 63 per cent).
Deloitte audit and assurance partner Dave Andrews said commodity price volatility made WA mining ripe for deals.
"There is a clear linkage between M&A priorities and the energy transition. We can expect it to continue to dominate 
the M&A landscape, but not in isolation, with the gold industry bringing together regional asset portfolios and 
building operational scale," he said.
The string of gold deals in the past 12 months has spanned Red 5 and Silverlake, Ramelius and Musgrave, 
Emerald and Bullseye, and Genesis and Dacian.
Westgold completed its $2.5 billion merger with Toronto-listed Karora last week to create a mid-tier gold producer.
Mr Andrews said Ramelius, which has done seven deals in six years, was "at it again" grabbing a near 18 per cent 
stake in Spartan.
Page 2 of 2
Big gains turn miners' eyes to M&A Returns
Speaking after Ramelius released June quarter results last week, chief executive Mark Zeptner said his company 
would take a wait and see approach on Spartan and its Never Never discovery.
"Whilst we'd like to have Never Never in our portfolio, we actually look at it as a nice to have, rather than a need to 
have," he said at the time.
Ramelius' $87 million spending spree on Spartan stock came after revelations Ramelius had been in takeover 
talks with Westgold late last year and that the two gold producers had agreed to a 12-month "mutual standstill".
Westgold moved on through the Karora merger. The sector is aiming to fill the void left by Newmont's acquisition of 
Newcrest Mining.
Load-Date: August 7, 2024
End of Document
| Mark Zeptner | Chief Executive Officer of Ramelius Resources | "Whilst we'd like to have Never Never in our portfolio, we actually look at it as a nice to have, rather than a need to have." |
